Hi, miene naam is Ron en ich kall noe plat met dich. Plat, of auch waal bekint es Limburgs, is â€™n Neder-Frankische taal die gesproake wurt in Belgisch Limburg, Nederlands Limburg en in â€™n deil van Dutsjland. In Dutsjland rondom Oake en â€™n bietsjke richting KÃ¶lle.

Limburgs wurt auch waal â€™n dialekt genumt, mÃ¨r â€™t versjil tÃ¶sje â€™n dialekt en â€™n taal is eigenlik neet duudelik. Sommige taaldeskundige zÃªgge dat â€™n taal, dat is â€™n dialekt mÃªt â€™n eige leger. WoadoeÃ«r â€™t zich zelf es stjandaart kint opdringe aan luj die angers kalle.

In Limburg zint dâ€™r net zoeÃ« vÃ¶Ã«l versjille tÃ¶sje luj, wie luj kalle in dÃ¶rp of in stjÃ¨he es wie in â€™n anger taal sproake is. Beveurbilt in Mestreech doa zit dâ€™r mieÃ« Frans in â€™t dialekt en in Kirchroade zit dâ€™r mieÃ« hoog-deutsch in â€˜t dialekt.

Limburgs is binne de regio woa â€™t gesproake wurt, vergelieÃ«ke mit de talen die dâ€™r rondomheen gesproake wÃ¨re, â€™n unieke taal omdat â€™t aspekte van â€™n toontaal hat.
â€™n Toontaal, dat wil zegge dat â€˜tzelfde woeÃ«rt doeÃ«r â€™n toeÃ«nverangering van beteikenis verangert.
In â€™t Limburgs wurt dat miestal gebroek om de meervoudsvorming aan te gÃ¨ve.
Beveurbilt: eine knieÃ«n - twieÃ« knieÃ«n, ein pÃ¨Ã¨Ã«rd - twieÃ« pÃ¨Ã¨Ã«rt, eine sjoon - twieÃ« sjoon.

Limburgs is â€™n taal die nog dageliks gesproake wurt. GewoeÃ«n auch op stjroat, mÃ¨r doe kins dâ€™r auch mit in â€™t gemeintehoeÃ«s of in â€™t ziekehoeÃ«s mit de luj. Dâ€™r zint dâ€™r auch genog die plat met dich kalle.
Op de schoeÃ«l echter, offisjÃ¨l wurt dâ€™r dan in de klas hollisj gekallt. Dus de kinger die liere dan sjrieve en lÃ¨Ã¨Ã«ze in â€™t hollisj op schoeÃ«l.

Nou dat woar â€™t eigenlik wat ich wouw zegge. En dan zeg ich op zâ€™n plat: hoije!
fields.Translation:
Hi, my name is Ron and I speak plat to you now. Plat, or also known as Limburgish, is a Low-Frankish language spoken in Belgian Limburg, Netherlands Limburg and in a part of Germany. In Germany in the neighborhood of Aachen and a little in the direction of KÃ¶ln.

Limburgish is also called a dialect, but the difference between a dialect and a language is unclear. Some language experts say that a language is a dialect with its own army. Therefore they can force themselves as a standard upon people who speak differently.

In Limburg there are just as much differences between people, as people talk in villages and cities as in another language. For example in Maastricht thereâ€™s a little French in the dialect and in Kerkrade thereâ€™s more High German in the dialect.

Limburgish is in the region where itâ€™s spoken unique as compared to the languages spoken in the neighborhood because it has got aspects of a tone language.
A tone language is meant to when the same word changes its meaning through a tone change.
In Limburgish thatâ€™s mostly used for the plural.
For instance: one rabit â€“ two rabbits, one horse â€“ two horses, one shoe â€“ two shoes.

Limburgish is a language thatâ€™s spoken daily. At street, but you can also speak it with people in the city hall or in the hospital. There are enough people whoâ€™ll talk Limburgish with you.
On school though, officially, they speak Dutch in the classroom. So, the children learn to write and read in Dutch at school.

So, thatâ€™s what I wanted to say.
And I say in plat: Take Care !
Demographics: 700,000 in Netherlands (2001). Population total all countries: 1,300,000.
